user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_auth_rq_header_:
```c
static bool
find_auth_rq_header_ (const struct MHD_Connection *c, enum MHD_AuthType type,
                      struct _MHD_str_w_len *auth_value)
{
  const struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *h;
  const char *token;
  size_t token_len;

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED <= c->state);
  if (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > c->state)
    return false;

#ifdef DAUTH_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_AUTHTYPE_DIGEST == type)
  {
    token = _MHD_AUTH_DIGEST_BASE;
    token_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (_MHD_AUTH_DIGEST_BASE);
  }
  else /* combined with the next line */
#endif /* DAUTH_SUPPORT */
#ifdef BAUTH_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_AUTHTYPE_BASIC == type)
  {
    token = _MHD_AUTH_BASIC_BASE;
    token_len = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (_MHD_AUTH_BASIC_BASE);
  }
  else /* combined with the next line */
#endif /* BAUTH_SUPPORT */
  {
    mhd_assert (0);
    return false;
  }

  for (h = c->rq.headers_received; NULL != h; h = h->next)
  {
    if (MHD_HEADER_KIND != h->kind)
      continue;
    if (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION) != h->header_size)
      continue;
    if (token_len > h->value_size)
      continue;
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION,
                                         h->header,
                                         MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                           MHD_HTTP_HEADER_AUTHORIZATION)))
      continue;
    if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (h->value, token, token_len))
      continue;
    /* Match only if token string is full header value or token is
     * followed by space or tab
     * Note: RFC 9110 (and RFC 7234) allows only space character, but
     * tab is supported here as well for additional flexibility and uniformity
     * as tabs are supported as separators between parameters.
     */
    if ((token_len == h->value_size) ||
        (' ' == h->value[token_len]) || ('\t'  == h->value[token_len]))
    {
      if (token_len != h->value_size)
      { /* Skip whitespace */
        auth_value->str = h->value + token_len + 1;
        auth_value->len = h->value_size - (token_len + 1);
      }
      else
      { /* No whitespace to skip */
        auth_value->str = h->value + token_len;
        auth_value->len = h->value_size - token_len;
      }
      return true; /* Found a match */
    }
  }
  return false; /* No matching header has been found */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function find_auth_rq_header_:
struct Session *next
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I flagged the above fragments because they are places where code can be (statically or configuration-dependently) unreachable or lead to control-flow situations that deserve inspection under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1:

- The top assert combined with the subsequent if/return: the assert documents an invariant but can be compiled out; the relationship between the assert and the runtime check should be reviewed so that there is no code made unreachable by assuming the assert (or conversely the check being always false). This construct can hide unreachable/assumed-to-be-impossible branches.

- The chained #ifdef / if / else / #endif blocks that end in mhd_assert(0); return false;: depending on DAUTH_SUPPORT/BAUTH_SUPPORT compile-time macros, the pairing of if/else and the final fallback block can produce different control-flow. This fallback (assert(0) + return) is the catch-all for unsupported types; it should be inspected to ensure no subsequent code depends on token/token_len when that fallback is taken, and that no branch is rendered unreachable across build configurations.

- The compound conditional that indexes h->value[token_len] and the subsequent inner if/else that uses token_len: although the code checks token_len > h->value_size earlier and the || expression is left-to-right (so the token_len == h->value_size case short-circuits the following array access), this sequence is subtle. Static analyzers or reviewers should verify that the accesses cannot be out-of-bounds and that neither branch is provably unreachable given the preceding checks and possible values of token_len/h->value_size.

Why other fragments need not be investigated here:
- The for-loop header and the simple header-kind and header-size comparisons are typical runtime checks and are not, by themselves, statically unreachable.
- The calls to the case-insensitive string comparison helpers and the final return false after the loop are reachable in normal control flow and do not present obvious unreachable-code issues.
- The branches inside the token-matching logic (other than the compound condition shown) are ordinary conditionals reachable when a matching header is present. They do not contain unconditional returns or constructs that would make subsequent code unreachable.

The three fragments above are the primary places where control-flow or build-configuration interactions can produce unreachable code or subtle dead branches; they should be inspected further by the investigators.
